name: MX Red
notes: The classic linear switch. Feels scratchy stock compared to modern competitors. Benefits significantly from lubing and filming. Still a solid reference point for the hobby.

name: MX Brown
notes: Often memed as 'scratchy linear' due to its subtle tactile bump. Many enthusiasts recommend upgrading to a proper tactile. Still popular in prebuilts for a reason - inoffensive and versatile.

name: MX Blue
notes: The iconic clicky switch. Click jacket mechanism produces a sharp audible click. Not recommended for shared office spaces. Kailh Box clickies are generally preferred by enthusiasts for a crisper click.

name: MX Black
notes: Heavier linear that some prefer for its resistance to accidental keypresses. Vintage Cherry Blacks (harvested from old boards) are highly sought after for their smoothness. New ones benefit from break-in and lubing.

name: MX Silent Red
notes: Silicone dampeners on stem reduce noise on both down and upstroke. Feels slightly mushy to some. Modern silent linears like Outemu Silent Lemon V3 and Boba U4 offer better feel at similar or lower prices.

name: MX Speed Silver
notes: Short actuation point designed for rapid inputs. Can lead to accidental keypresses for those not used to it. Gateron and Kailh speed switches are smoother stock alternatives.

name: MX Clear
notes: Much more pronounced tactile bump than MX Brown with a heavy bottom-out. Progressive spring ramps up steeply. Popular for Ergo-Clear mod (lighter spring swap). Stock spring can be fatiguing for some.

name: Yellow
notes: The gold standard budget linear. Smooth stock and incredible value. Lubed and filmed Gateron Yellows are a rite of passage for keyboard enthusiasts. Milky top version adds deeper sound.

name: Oil King
notes: Full nylon construction produces a deep, thocky sound profile. Factory lubed and smooth. Very popular for builds aiming for that deep, full-bodied sound. Some prefer to re-lube for consistency.

name: Milky Yellow Pro
notes: Pre-lubed upgrade to the classic Gateron Yellow. Milky housing adds warmth to the sound. One of the best value propositions in the hobby. Great stock, even better with a touch more lube.

name: Pro 3.0 Red
notes: Factory pre-lubed with improved mold tolerances over previous Gateron generations. Solid stock experience. Dustproof stem design. Good stepping stone from Cherry MX Red.

name: Pro 3.0 Brown
notes: Improved over older Gateron Browns with factory lube and tighter tolerances. Still a mild tactile bump. For more pronounced tactility, look at Boba U4T or Durock T1.

name: G Pro 3.0 Silver
notes: Short travel speed switch with factory lube. Smoother than Cherry Speed Silver out of the box. Short actuation takes getting used to for typing but great for competitive gaming.

name: Ink Black V2
notes: One of the most popular premium linears. Ink housing produces a deep, satisfying sound. Very smooth when lubed with Krytox 205g0. Stock springs can be slightly pingy - spring swap or bag lube recommended.

name: Ink Red V2
notes: Lighter version of Ink Black V2. Same excellent ink housing sound profile with less resistance. Great for those who want the Ink sound but prefer lighter springs. Benefits from lubing and filming.

name: CJ
notes: Collaboration with keyboard enthusiast CJ. Full nylon housing for deep sound. Two-stage spring provides unique weight curve. Great stock but can be improved with hand-lubing. Competes well with Oil King.

name: North Pole
notes: Designed specifically for north-facing PCBs - no interference issues. Long pole stem gives a satisfying clacky bottom-out. Factory lubed and smooth stock. Great all-around mid-range linear.

name: Cap V2 Yellow
notes: Cap switch design with unique top housing geometry for reduced wobble. Creamy smooth with factory lube. A nice step up from Milky Yellows without breaking the bank.

name: Cap V2 Brown
notes: Cap design reduces stem wobble for better feel. Subtle but clean tactile bump. Better than standard Gateron Brown but still lighter tactility than enthusiast options. Good for those who want gentle feedback.

name: Box Jade
notes: Thick click bar mechanism produces one of the crispest, most satisfying clicks in the hobby. Very loud - not for office use. The heavier click bar compared to Box White gives a more substantial click. A community favorite for clicky lovers.

name: Box Navy
notes: The heavy-handed sibling of Box Jade. Thick click bar with a heavier spring makes for an extremely tactile and loud typing experience. Can be fatiguing for long sessions. Feels like a tiny typewriter.

name: Box White
notes: Click bar mechanism is sharper and more consistent than Cherry click jacket. Lighter than Box Jade making it better for extended typing. Box stem design provides IP56 dust and moisture resistance.

name: Box Brown
notes: Box stem design gives slightly more defined bump than Cherry Brown. Dustproof and waterproof stem. Still a light tactile - enthusiasts wanting more bump should look at Boba U4T or Durock T1.

name: Box Red
notes: Box stem provides stability and dust resistance. Smoother than Cherry Red stock. Shorter travel than standard MX switches. Solid budget choice for gaming-focused builds.

name: Speed Silver
notes: Very short actuation point for rapid input registration. Light spring weight means minimal effort per press. Takes adjustment if coming from standard travel switches. Not ideal for typing-heavy work.

name: Speed Copper
notes: Rare speed tactile switch. Short actuation with a quick tactile bump near the top. Useful for gamers who want some feedback without the full travel. Bump is subtle due to short travel distance.

name: Midnight Pro Silent
notes: Dual silicone dampeners minimize both downstroke and upstroke noise. Factory lubed for smooth operation. One of the better mass-market silent linears. Less mushy feel than Cherry Silent Red.

name: POM Linear
notes: Full POM housing is naturally self-lubricating and produces an incredibly deep sound. One of the deepest sounding switches available. Minimal need for additional lube. Medium-heavy weight suits controlled typing.

name: T1
notes: Large, rounded tactile bump that is satisfying without being sharp. Very popular mid-range tactile. JWK manufactured. Smoky housing version has slightly different sound. Great lubed with Tribosys 3203.

name: L7
notes: JWK-manufactured smooth linear with tight tolerances. Very little stem wobble. Comes in multiple colors/weights. Factory lube is decent but benefits from hand lubing. Solid all-around performer.

name: Sunflower
notes: Full POM housing similar to Durock POM Linear with a different spring weight and gold-plated spring. Deep, thocky sound profile. Heavier weight provides good control. Self-lubricating POM is low maintenance.

name: Black V2
notes: Also known as Alpaca V2. One of the smoothest stock linears available. JWK's refined molds produce exceptional consistency. Lubed with Krytox 205g0 these are many enthusiasts' endgame linear. Slightly clacky PC housing.

name: Lavender
notes: Nylon housing gives a deeper, creamier sound compared to PC-housed JWK switches. Same incredible JWK smoothness as the Alpaca V2. Beautiful lavender colorway. One of the community's top linear recommendations.

name: Durock Daybreak
notes: Heavier JWK linear with a beautiful teal colorway. 67g actuation is on the heavier side but provides excellent control and deliberate keypresses. Same JWK smoothness as Alpaca V2. Gorgeous switch aesthetics.

name: Meteor White
notes: Surprisingly smooth for the price point. SP-Star's improved mold quality puts these near JWK levels of smoothness. Clean white colorway. Great value mid-range linear that punches above its weight.

name: Polaris Gray
notes: Clean, no-nonsense linear with good smoothness at a reasonable price. PC housing gives a slightly higher-pitched, poppier sound than the Meteor White. Consistent factory lube application. Underrated option.

name: Boba U4T
notes: Widely considered the gold standard for tactile switches. Large, round D-shaped bump with a thocky sound profile. Long pole stem provides satisfying bottom-out. Many prefer stock without lube to preserve tactility. Tight housing means no need for films.

name: Boba U4
notes: Silent version of the U4T with rubber dampeners. Retains the excellent tactile bump while being near-silent. One of the best silent tactiles available. No mushy feel like many silent switches. Housing is tight, no films needed.

name: Zealios V2 62g
notes: Sharp, pronounced tactile bump at the top of the keystroke. Premium pricing is controversial - many feel Boba U4T offers similar or better tactility for less. Still an excellent switch with a unique bump profile. Clear housing allows RGB shine-through.

name: Zealios V2 67g
notes: The most popular Zealios weight. Sharper, snappier bump compared to the rounder U4T. Premium priced but exceptional build quality. PMMA housing is somewhat brittle - be careful when opening. Sounds best with a light lube on springs only.

name: CS Lavender Purple
notes: Very light tactile that is easy on the fingers. Good entry-level tactile at an incredible price. More noticeable bump than Cherry Brown. Akko's CS line offers insane value across the board.

name: CS Radiant Red
notes: Light, smooth budget linear from Akko. Factory lubed with decent smoothness out of the box. Outperforms Cherry MX Red at a fraction of the price. Great for budget gaming builds.

name: CS Jelly Pink
notes: Budget speed linear with shorter travel and actuation. Great alternative to expensive Kailh or Cherry speed switches. Smooth with factory lube. Shorter travel takes some adjustment for typing.

name: V3 Cream Yellow
notes: Akko's V3 line represents a significant step up from the CS series. Creamy, smooth sound profile. Upgraded molds and better factory lube application. Competes with switches twice its price. One of the best budget linears available.

name: V3 Cream Blue
notes: Improved tactile from Akko's V3 line. More defined bump than CS Lavender Purple while maintaining a smooth, creamy feel. Great value tactile option. Factory lube is well-applied for the price range.

name: V3 Matcha Green
notes: Same internals as V3 Cream Yellow with a matcha green colorway. Pairs beautifully with green-themed builds. Smooth factory lube and creamy sound. Another excellent budget linear from Akko.

name: Xinhai
notes: HMX has been a rising star in the switch game. Extended spring with long pole stem creates a snappy, clacky sound. Excellent smoothness for the price. Strong competitor in the mid-range. A community darling.

name: Cloud
notes: Lighter version in the HMX lineup. Very light spring weight creates an effortless typing experience. Extended spring reduces ping. Excellent smoothness stock. One of the best light linears at this price point.

name: Purple Panda
notes: Marketed as a budget Holy Panda alternative. Large tactile bump with a thocky sound. PME housing material is unique and contributes to the deep sound. Long pole gives a definitive bottom-out feel. Great value for tactile lovers.

name: Sapphire V2
notes: UHMWPE stem is inherently smooth and self-lubricating. Clean tactile bump with a clacky sound signature. V2 fixed some of the V1's tolerance issues. Interesting alternative for tactile fans wanting a different material feel.

name: Ice Candy Nylon
notes: Full nylon housing with UHMWPE stem for a deep, thocky sound. Long pole adds definition to the bottom-out. UHMWPE material is very smooth by nature. Unique translucent stem is visually interesting. Good mid-range option.

name: Strawberry
notes: Incredible value - one of the cheapest long pole switches available. Poppy, higher-pitched sound signature. Factory lube is decent. Extended spring helps with ping. KTT has been a revelation in budget switches.

name: Kang White V3
notes: One of the most recommended budget linears. V3 improves on already excellent V2. Nylon housing gives creamy sound. Long pole and extended spring combo is satisfying. Competes with switches three times its price. A must-try for budget builders.

name: Peach
notes: Deeper, thockier variant in the KTT lineup. Mixed housing material creates a balanced sound. Long pole provides satisfying bottom-out. Slightly heavier than Strawberry for a more controlled feel. Another KTT budget winner.

name: Morandi
notes: Named after the muted color palette of Giorgio Morandi paintings. Long pole with extended spring for a clean, clacky sound. Excellent smoothness. Has gained a strong following in the community for its unique sound signature.

name: Aurora
notes: PC housing gives a higher-pitched, poppier sound compared to the nylon Morandi. Light spring weight for effortless typing. Extended spring eliminates ping. Good choice for those who prefer brighter sound profiles.

name: Silent Lemon V3
notes: Outstanding budget silent linear. V3 revision dramatically improved smoothness and reduced mushiness. Dual silicone dampeners are well-tuned. Rivals switches at twice the price. Top recommendation for budget silent builds.

name: Silent Cream
notes: Budget silent tactile with a noticeable bump. Less premium feel than Boba U4 but at less than half the price. Silicone dampeners work well. Factory lube is acceptable. Great for office keyboards where silence matters.

name: Gold Pink V2
notes: One of the lightest mainstream linears available at 37g actuation. Extremely effortless keypresses. Gold-plated spring adds corrosion resistance. V2 improved smoothness over original. Not for heavy-handed typists - accidental presses are common.

name: Bluish White
notes: Light tactile with a crisp, clean bump. More defined than Cherry Brown at a lighter weight. TTC's gold-plated springs are a nice touch at this price point. Clean typing experience with minimal fatigue.

name: Silent Frozen
notes: TTC's entry in the silent linear category. Dual dampening system with gold-plated spring. Smooth and quiet with less mushiness than Cherry Silent Red. Attractive translucent icy blue housing. Solid mid-range silent option.

name: Cream
notes: Full POM construction pioneer that helped popularize the 'creamy' sound descriptor. Scratchy out of the box and needs extensive break-in period (200k+ keypresses) or lube. Once broken in, very smooth with a unique sound signature. Iconic switch in the hobby's history.

name: Silk Series Yellow
notes: JWK-manufactured and factory lubed with a NovelKeys-proprietary blend. Very smooth stock - one of the best factory lube jobs in the hobby. Silk name is apt - genuinely silky feel. Good choice for those who do not want to hand-lube.

name: Aqua King V3
notes: Fully transparent housing and stem make this the king of RGB builds. Pre-lubed and smooth. PC-on-PC contact creates a unique higher-pitched sound. V3 fixed the over-lubing issues of earlier versions. Striking visual appearance.

name: WS Onion
notes: Light linear with a satisfying clacky long pole bottom-out. Extended spring prevents ping. Nylon housing adds warmth to the clack. Smooth factory lube. Part of Wuque Studio's well-regarded WS switch lineup.

name: WS Heavy Tactile
notes: One of the better mid-range heavy tactiles. Large D-shaped bump with a satisfying, thocky bottom-out from the long pole. Extended spring eliminates ping. Nylon housing contributes to the deeper sound. Competes well with Boba U4T at a lower price.

name: Tangerine V2
notes: UHMWPE housing is inherently self-lubricating, making this one of the smoothest linears. JWK manufactured. Iconic orange colorway. Available in 62g and 67g variants. A longtime community favorite for buttery smooth linears.

name: Banana Split
notes: JWK manufactured with a striking yellow stem and purple housing colorway. Same excellent JWK smoothness. Popular for themed builds. Sound is very similar to Alpaca V2. The look alone sells these for many builders.

name: Holy Panda X
notes: The latest iteration of the legendary Holy Panda. Large, sharp tactile bump with a snappy return. Community opinions are divided - some feel original Invyr Pandas were better. Still a solid tactile but faces stiff competition from Boba U4T at a lower price.

name: Matcha Latte
notes: Beautiful matcha and cream colorway with excellent performance. Long pole delivers a clean clacky bottom-out. Extended spring eliminates ping. Smooth factory lube. One of the best-looking switches that also performs exceptionally well.

name: MX Hyperglide Red
notes: Updated molds from Cherry with improved smoothness over original MX Red. Hyperglide designation indicates the new tooling. Still not as smooth as Gateron or JWK stock but a noticeable improvement. Cherry loyalists appreciate the upgrade.

name: Nebula
notes: Deep, thocky sound from nylon housing and long pole combo. Extended spring for a pingless experience. Smooth factory lube. Good mid-range competitor in the increasingly crowded long pole linear space.

name: Box Ink V2 Black
notes: Combines the beloved Ink housing with a Box-style dustproof stem. Reduced stem wobble compared to standard Ink V2. Maintains the deep, thocky Ink sound. Factory lubed. Premium pricing justified by the refined design.

name: Shadow
notes: Budget long pole linear that delivers surprisingly deep sound. Aflion has been gaining reputation for quality budget switches. Factory lube is decent. Extended spring helps with ping. Great value thocky option.

name: Holy Tom V2
notes: Budget tactile with a large, satisfying bump reminiscent of Holy Pandas. Long pole adds definition. Huano's manufacturing quality has improved significantly. V2 addresses the scratchiness issues of V1. Excellent value tactile.

name: MX2A Silent Red
notes: Cherry's MX2A revision with improved molds and factory lube. Noticeably smoother than the original Silent Red. Updated dampening material reduces mushiness. Cherry finally catching up to competitors in the silent switch space.

name: Diced Fruit
notes: Extremely light and poppy budget switch. Extended spring and long pole at an unbelievable price point. Factory lube is thin but functional. Higher-pitched sound from PC housing. Great ultra-budget option for light typists.

name: T1
notes: Ultra-budget linear with surprisingly good smoothness. JWICK (also known as JWICK/Dongguan Golden Orange) has earned respect for budget switch quality. Factory lube is acceptable. Hard to beat at this price point.

name: Princess Linear
notes: Budget long pole linear with a creamy sound signature from the nylon housing. Well-lubed stock. MMD switches offer surprising quality for the price. Extended spring combo is satisfying and ping-free.

name: Mint Panda
notes: Originally popular as a housing donor for Holy Panda frankenswitches. Decent standalone tactile with a rounded bump. The Panda housing is the star - pairs well with Halo stems. Less relevant now that factory Holy Pandas exist.

name: Quinn
notes: Gateron's response to the long pole trend. Extended spring and long pole stem create a satisfying clacky bottom-out. Nylon housing adds depth. Factory lube is well-applied. A nice middle ground between North Pole and Oil King.

name: Voyager
notes: Budget tactile with a pronounced bump and long pole bottom-out. Nylon housing contributes to a deep, thocky sound. Factory lube is decent. Solid competitor in the budget tactile space alongside Tecsee Purple Panda.

name: Milky Yellow Pro
notes: The milky housing variant of the beloved Gateron Yellow. Milky top and bottom housing produce a deeper, thockier sound than the clear housing version. Factory lube is adequate. One of the best budget linears ever made.

name: Oil King
notes: Gateron's thock king. Full nylon INK housing with an opaque black stem produces one of the deepest sounds in the hobby. Long spring eliminates ping. Factory lube is generous and well-applied. A top-tier linear without breaking the bank.

name: Box Ink Black V2
notes: Box-stem variant of the Ink V2 series with improved dust and moisture resistance. The box design reduces stem wobble significantly. Deep thocky sound from the INK housing. Premium feel at a premium price.

name: Box Ink Pink V2
notes: The lighter sibling in the Box Ink V2 lineup. Combines the dust-resistant box stem with the smooth INK housing. Light actuation makes it great for gaming while the INK housing keeps the sound profile premium and creamy.

name: CJ
notes: Designed with KeebMonkey, the CJ delivers a refined creamy sound. Full nylon housing with a well-lubed POM stem. Gold-plated spring eliminates ping. Smooth stock without needing additional lube. A favorite among mid-range linear enthusiasts.

name: CS Jelly Black
notes: Transparent PC housing with a medium weight. Part of Akko's budget Jelly series. Decent factory lube. The PC housing gives a slightly higher pitch than nylon variants but still achieves a pleasant thocky tone at a very low price.

name: CS Jelly Blue
notes: Budget clicky from Akko's Jelly line. Click jacket mechanism with a clear PC housing. The transparent housing makes RGB shine nicely. A solid budget alternative to Cherry MX Blue with better factory smoothness.

name: CS Jelly White
notes: Ultra-light linear from the Jelly series. At 35g actuation, this is one of the lightest budget switches available. The PC housing with factory lube gives a surprisingly smooth and creamy sound. Great for those who prefer feather-light keypresses.

name: V3 Cream Yellow
notes: Akko's long pole cream switch at an incredible price. Extended spring eliminates ping, and the long pole stem creates a satisfying clacky bottom-out. Nylon bottom + PC top housing combo. Factory lube is surprisingly consistent for the price.

name: V3 Cream Blue
notes: Tactile variant of the V3 Cream series. Moderate tactile bump with a satisfying long pole clack at bottom-out. Extended spring keeps it ping-free. An excellent budget tactile that competes with switches costing twice as much.

name: Durock L7
notes: JWK's workhorse linear. Smooth nylon housing with a well-lubed stem. Heavier spring gives a more deliberate feel. JWK factory quality is consistently excellent. A reliable mid-range choice for those who want smooth without overpaying.

name: T1
notes: A benchmark mid-range tactile. Large, rounded tactile bump positioned near the top of the stroke. Nylon housing produces a satisfying thock. Factory lube is generous. Often recommended as a step up from Cherry MX Brown.

name: Sunflower
notes: Full POM housing gives the Sunflower a uniquely deep and thocky sound. The self-lubricating POM material means it feels smoother stock than most tactiles. Moderate tactile bump. A hidden gem in the Durock lineup.

name: Strawberry
notes: Budget poppy linear that punches way above its price. PC housing gives it a bright, lively sound. Factory lube is thin but serviceable. A favorite in the ultra-budget community for its cheerful, snappy character.

name: Kang White V3
notes: The budget linear king. Long pole stem with extended spring at an absurd price. Smooth stock with decent factory lube. The V3 revision improved wobble and consistency. Nearly impossible to beat at this price-to-performance ratio.

name: Peach
notes: A mellow budget linear with nylon housing for a warmer sound. Not as exciting as the Strawberry or Kang White but offers a more relaxed typing experience. Good for those who want cream without the price of Cream switches.

name: Sea Salt Lemon
notes: Light and snappy budget linear with long pole and extended spring. PC housing contributes to a brighter tone than the nylon Peach. Factory lube is adequate. Competes directly with KTT Strawberry but with a creamier sound profile.

name: Meteor White
notes: SP-Star's flagship linear. Incredibly smooth stock with excellent factory lube. Nylon housing delivers a warm, creamy sound. Medium-heavy weight feels deliberate without being tiring. One of the best mid-range linears available.

name: Polaris Gray
notes: Heavy linear with deep thocky sound. SP-Star's smooth factory finish is excellent. The 67g actuation makes it one of the heavier linears but fans love the deliberate, controlled feel. Pairs especially well with aluminum plates.

name: Silent Lemon
notes: One of the best ultra-budget silent switches. Silicone dampeners effectively mute both downstroke and upstroke. Light actuation force makes typing effortless. The V3 revision significantly improved smoothness over previous versions.

name: Silent Peach
notes: Silent tactile from Outemu with a noticeable bump and dampened bottom-out. Nylon housing keeps the muted sound profile consistent. A strong budget alternative to the much pricier Boba U4 for silent tactile fans.

name: Gold Pink V2
notes: Ultra-light linear famous for its featherweight feel. Gold-plated spring eliminates ping. The V2 improved stem mold for less wobble. PC housing gives a bright, poppy sound. Not for heavy-handed typists who will bottom out constantly.

name: Bluish White
notes: Light tactile with a crisp bump near the top of the stroke. PC housing gives a clean, defined sound. One of the best light tactiles in the budget range. The bump is more noticeable than MX Brown but lighter than Durock T1.

name: Silent Blueberry
notes: TTC's silent tactile option. Dampened downstroke and upstroke with a moderate tactile bump. The silencing pads are well-implemented without feeling overly mushy. A solid mid-range silent tactile option.

name: MX2A Red
notes: Cherry's updated MX Red with improved smoothness and factory lube. The MX2A generation significantly closed the gap with competitors like Gateron. Still not as smooth as top-tier budget switches but a massive improvement over original MX.

name: MX2A Brown
notes: Updated MX Brown with factory lube and a slightly more pronounced bump. Cherry's attempt to reclaim territory from Gateron and Akko budget tactiles. Better than original MX Brown but still faces stiff competition.

name: MX2A Blue
notes: The updated MX Blue with improved manufacturing. Click jacket mechanism remains the same but the housing mold and lube are improved. Still outclassed by Kailh Box clickies for crispness and consistency.

name: Purple Panda
notes: A budget Holy Panda alternative with a similar large tactile bump. PME housing material gives a unique feel. The bump is sharp and satisfying. Great for those who want the Panda experience without the Panda price.

name: Ice Candy
notes: Unique UHMWPE stem in a clear PC housing. The UHMWPE material is incredibly smooth without lube. Long pole stem gives a satisfying poppy bottom-out. The transparent look is great for RGB builds. A fun, lively switch.

name: Sapphire V2
notes: Heavier tactile with UHMWPE bottom housing for natural smoothness. Large, well-defined bump. The V2 improved stem mold and spring consistency. Underrated in the tactile space, offering a unique material combination.

name: WS Morandi
notes: A refined tactile from Wuque Studio with a gentle, rounded bump. Long spring and long pole create a distinct creamy bottom-out. Excellent factory lube. Popular among those who want a subtle tactile that doesn't interrupt typing flow.

name: Xinhai
notes: HMX's breakout switch that put the brand on the map. Long pole with extended spring at a budget price. The nylon + PC housing combo gives a poppy yet controlled sound. Well-lubed stock. Excellent value proposition.

name: Hyacinth V2
notes: The Hyacinth V2 refines the formula with full nylon housing for a deeper, thockier sound than the Xinhai. Extended spring and long pole. Factory lube is excellent. Quickly becoming a community favorite in the mid-budget linear segment.

name: Frog V3
notes: A community favorite for deep thock. Full nylon housing with long spring eliminates any hint of ping. The Frog V3 is incredibly smooth stock. Excellent factory lube. Competes directly with Gateron Oil King for the thock crown.

name: Boba U4T
notes: The king of tactile switches. Large, crisp tactile bump with a satisfying thocky bottom-out from the long pole stem. Nylon housing provides deep sound. Uniquely tight housing tolerance means no wobble and no need for films. Best left unlubed to preserve the sharp bump.
